10870Journal of Chemical CrystallographyJ Chem Crystallogr1074-15421572-8854Springer USBostons10870-013-0402-540210.1007/s10870-013-0402-5Original PaperHydrothermal Synthesis, Structure, and Luminescence of a U(VI) ComplexSeveranceRachel C.1CorteseAnthony J.1SmithMark D.1zur LoyeHans-Conrad1dgrid.254567.7000000009075106XDepartment of Chemistry and BiochemistryUniversity of South Carolina631 Sumter Street29208ColumbiaSCUSA+1-803-777-6916+1-803-777-8508zurloye@mailbox.sc.edu133201342013434171177252201334201225220131332013© Springer Science+Business Media New York 20132013Abstract

A new complex, Na2(H2O)2UO2(PDC)2 (1), has been synthesized from the ligand pyridine-2,5-dicarboxylic acid (H2PDC) and uranyl acetate. The crystal structure of compound 1 was determined by single-crystal diffraction. The compound crystallizes in the triclinic space group P-1, with a = 8.0606(6) Å, b = 11.3274(8) Å, c = 11.6584(8) Å, α = 116.7790(10)°, β = 107.4170(10)°, and γ = 90.9540(10)°. Compound 1 was further characterized by powder X-ray diffraction, luminescence spectroscopy, and UV–vis absorbance spectroscopy.

Graphical Abstract

A new complex, Na2(H2O)2UO2(PDC)2, was synthesized from the ligand pyridine-2,5-dicarboxylic acid (H2PDC) and uranyl acetate, and was characterized via single-crystal diffraction, powder X-ray diffraction, luminescence spectroscopy, and UV-Vis absorbance spectroscopy.

KeywordsHydrothermal synthesisPyridine-2,5-dicarboxylic acidUranyl acetateLuminescencepublisher-imprint-nameSpringervolume-issue-count12issue-article-count7issue-toc-levels0issue-pricelist-year2013issue-copyright-holderSpringer Science+Business Media New Yorkissue-copyright-year2013article-contains-esmNoarticle-numbering-styleUnnumberedarticle-registration-date-year2013article-registration-date-month2article-registration-date-day25article-toc-levels0toc-levels0volume-typeRegularjournal-productArchiveJournalnumbering-styleUnnumberedarticle-grants-typeRegularmetadata-grantOpenAccessabstract-grantOpenAccessbodypdf-grantRestrictedbodyhtml-grantRestrictedbibliography-grantRestrictedesm-grantOpenAccessonline-firstfalsepdf-file-referenceBodyRef/PDF/10870_2013_Article_402.pdftarget-typeOnlinePDFissue-online-date-year2013issue-online-date-month4issue-online-date-day4issue-print-date-year2013issue-print-date-month4issue-print-date-day3issue-typeRegulararticle-typeOriginalPaperjournal-subject-primaryChemistryjournal-subject-secondaryOrganometallic Chemistryjournal-subject-secondaryCrystallographyjournal-subject-secondaryPhysical Chemistryjournal-subject-secondaryInorganic Chemistryjournal-subject-collectionChemistry and Materials Scienceopen-accessfalseIntroduction

Organic–inorganic hybrid materials containing the uranyl cation contain two notable features: the positively charged metal–oxo uranyl cluster, and the negatively charged organic ligands [1]. The use of the uranyl (UO22+) cation as a metal–oxo cluster in place of the more traditional transition metal allows increased stability due to the strong U–O bond [2]. Additionally, as a hard acidic species, the uranyl cation is known for binding both to oxygen and nitrogen atoms, allowing for a wide variety of coordination chemistry involving carboxylate, phosphonate, and heterocyclic groups [3–8]. It is a highly luminescent species, and among the most studied ions of the actinide series [9–14]. Furthermore, several uranyl-containing systems have been found useful for photocatalytic properties, as the excited uranyl ion is a strong oxidant [15, 16].

A new complex, Na2(H2O)2UO2(PDC)2 (1), was synthesized from the ligand pyridine-2,5-dicarboxylic acid (H2PDC) and uranyl acetate in the presence of sodium bicarbonate. The crystal structure of compound 1 was determined by single-crystal diffraction. Compound 1 was further characterized by powder X-ray diffraction, luminescence spectroscopy, and UV–vis absorbance spectroscopy.

ExperimentalMaterials and Methods

All solvents and reagents were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification. All heating and cooling was performed in a Fisher Scientific Isotemp programmable oven, at a rate of 1 and 0.1 °C/min, respectively. Caution: uranyl acetate contains depleted uranium, but standard precautions for handling radioactive and highly toxic substances should be followed.

Hydrothermal Synthesis of Na<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>UO<sub>2</sub>(PDC)<sub>2</sub> (<bold>1</bold>)

Uranyl acetate (0.25 mmol, 106 mg), pyridine-2,5-dicarboxylic acid (H2PDC) (0.50 mmol, 84 mg), and 0.5 mL aqueous sodium bicarbonate (pH 8.5) were combined in a 9 mm glass tube and flame sealed under vacuum. The tube was heated to 80 °C, held for 12 h, heated to 190 °C, held for 3 days, cooled to 80 °C, held for 12 h, and finally cooled to room temperature. Crystals of 1 formed under autogenous pressure as yellow needles in quantitative yield based on stoichiometric ratio.

Single-Crystal X-Ray Crystallography

X-ray intensity data from a yellow needle crystal were measured at 100(2) K using a Bruker SMART APEX diffractometer (Mo Kα radiation, λ = 0.71073 Å) [17]. The raw area detector data frames were reduced and corrected for absorption effects with the SAINT+ and SADABS programs [17]. Final unit cell parameters were determined by least-squares refinement of 8,324 reflections from the data set. Direct methods structure solution, difference Fourier calculations and full-matrix least-squares refinement against F2 were performed with SHELXTL [18]. The compound crystallizes in the triclinic system. The space group P-1 was confirmed by the successful solution and refinement of the structure. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. Hydrogen atoms bonded to carbon were placed in geometrically idealized positions and included as riding atoms. The water hydrogen atoms were located in difference maps and refined isotropically with all O–H distances restrained to be similar (SHELX SADI instruction, six restraints). The largest residual electron density peak is located 0.92 Å from the uranium atom. Crystallographic data are given in Table 1. Selected bond distances and angles are given in Table 2, and hydrogen bonds are detailed in Table 3.

Powder X-Ray Diffraction

Ground crystals of 1 were used to collect PXRD patterns using a Rigaku Ultima IV Powder Diffractometer equipped with a high speed DTex detector (Cu Kα radiation λ = 1.5418 Å) over the 2θ range of 5–80°, with a step size of 0.02° and a scan speed of 10°/min. The measured pattern of 1 matches the diffraction pattern generated by CrystalMaker 8.0 using the single-crystal data, and does not reveal any measurable impurities in the sample (Fig. 1).

UV–Vis Spectrometry

Ground crystals of 1 and ground polycrystalline powders of H2PDC and uranyl acetate were used to collect diffuse-reflectance spectra using a Perkin-Elmer Lambda 35 UV–vis scanning spectrometer equipped with an integrating sphere. The raw data were converted from reflection to absorbance by the use of the Kubelka–Munk function.

Photoluminescence Measurements

Ground crystals of 1 and ground polycrystalline powders of H2PDC and uranyl acetate were used to collect excitation and emission spectra using a Perkin-Elmer LS 55 Fluorescence Spectrometer. All measurements were collected at room temperature. Emission spectra were collected with excitation at 335 nm and an excitation filter at 390 nm. Excitation spectra were collected with emission at 513 nm.

Results and DiscussionStructural Description of Na<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>UO<sub>2</sub>(PDC)<sub>2</sub> (<bold>1</bold>)

The asymmetric unit consists of one UO22+ group, two sodium atoms, two PDC ligands and two water molecules, as shown in Fig. 2. Each PDC ligand chelates one uranyl cation with both a pyridyl nitrogen and a carboxylate oxygen, and links that uranyl center to a second uranyl center via an oxygen of the second carboxylate group. Thus, the uranyl groups are linked together into chains as shown in Fig. 3. The carboxylate groups are also extensively coordinated to sodium ions, and form clusters with sodium and water via both covalent and hydrogen bonds, as shown in Fig. 4. Overall, a three dimensional network is formed, as shown in Fig. 5.

Photoluminescence and UV–Vis Absorbance

As can be seen in Figs. 6 and 7, the primary source of the photoluminescent properties of compound 1 is the uranyl cation. A slight blue shift of the luminescence occurs, but overall the typical multi-band signature of U(VI) is in evidence. A lower excitation band near that of the uncoordinated H2PDC molecule is also present near 230 nm in addition to the typical regions of excitation for U(VI). The UV–vis absorbance is very broad, as is typically observed for many U(VI) compounds (Fig. 8) [19, 20].

Conclusions

A new uranium containing framework material was synthesized hydrothermally and characterized via single-crystal diffraction, powder X-ray diffraction, luminescence spectroscopy, and UV–vis spectroscopy.

Supplementary Materials

Crystallographic data for the structures reported in this paper have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre as supplementary publication number CCDC 856641. These data can be obtained free of charge via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif, or by emailing data_request@ccdc.cam.ac.uk, or by contacting The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, 12, Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK; fax: +44 1223 336033.

Acknowledgments

Mary Anne Fitzpatrick, Dean, and the USC Selection Committee are gratefully acknowledged for supporting Rachel Severance via a College of Arts and Sciences Dean’s Dissertation Fellowship. Research supported by the U.S. Department of Energy, Office of Basic Energy Sciences, Division of Materials Sciences and Engineering under Award DE-SC0008664.

elements.content: All solvents and reagents were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification. All heating and cooling was performed in a Fisher Scientific Isotemp programmable oven, at a rate of 1 and 0.1 °C/min, respectively. Caution: uranyl acetate contains depleted uranium, but standard precautions for handling radioactive and highly toxic substances should be followed.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Materials and Methods

All solvents and reagents were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification. All heating and cooling was performed in a Fisher Scientific Isotemp programmable oven, at a rate of 1 and 0.1 °C/min, respectively. Caution: uranyl acetate contains depleted uranium, but standard precautions for handling radioactive and highly toxic substances should be followed.

elements.content: Uranyl acetate (0.25 mmol, 106 mg), pyridine-2,5-dicarboxylic acid (H2PDC) (0.50 mmol, 84 mg), and 0.5 mL aqueous sodium bicarbonate (pH 8.5) were combined in a 9 mm glass tube and flame sealed under vacuum. The tube was heated to 80 °C, held for 12 h, heated to 190 °C, held for 3 days, cooled to 80 °C, held for 12 h, and finally cooled to room temperature. Crystals of 1 formed under autogenous pressure as yellow needles in quantitative yield based on stoichiometric ratio.
elements.clean_text:
Hydrothermal Synthesis of Na2(H2O)2UO2(PDC)2 (1)

Uranyl acetate (0.25 mmol, 106 mg), pyridine-2,5-dicarboxylic acid (H2PDC) (0.50 mmol, 84 mg), and 0.5 mL aqueous sodium bicarbonate (pH 8.5) were combined in a 9 mm glass tube and flame sealed under vacuum. The tube was heated to 80 °C, held for 12 h, heated to 190 °C, held for 3 days, cooled to 80 °C, held for 12 h, and finally cooled to room temperature. Crystals of 1 formed under autogenous pressure as yellow needles in quantitative yield based on stoichiometric ratio.

elements.content: X-ray intensity data from a yellow needle crystal were measured at 100(2) K using a Bruker SMART APEX diffractometer (Mo Kα radiation, λ = 0.71073 Å) [17]. The raw area detector data frames were reduced and corrected for absorption effects with the SAINT+ and SADABS programs [17]. Final unit cell parameters were determined by least-squares refinement of 8,324 reflections from the data set. Direct methods structure solution, difference Fourier calculations and full-matrix least-squares refinement against F2 were performed with SHELXTL [18]. The compound crystallizes in the triclinic system. The space group P-1 was confirmed by the successful solution and refinement of the structure. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. Hydrogen atoms bonded to carbon were placed in geometrically idealized positions and included as riding atoms. The water hydrogen atoms were located in difference maps and refined isotropically with all O–H distances restrained to be similar (SHELX SADI instruction, six restraints). The largest residual electron density peak is located 0.92 Å from the uranium atom. Crystallographic data are given in Table 1. Selected bond distances and angles are given in Table 2, and hydrogen bonds are detailed in Table 3.
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal X-Ray Crystallography

X-ray intensity data from a yellow needle crystal were measured at 100(2) K using a Bruker SMART APEX diffractometer (Mo Kα radiation, λ = 0.71073 Å) [17]. The raw area detector data frames were reduced and corrected for absorption effects with the SAINT+ and SADABS programs [17]. Final unit cell parameters were determined by least-squares refinement of 8,324 reflections from the data set. Direct methods structure solution, difference Fourier calculations and full-matrix least-squares refinement against F2 were performed with SHELXTL [18]. The compound crystallizes in the triclinic system. The space group P-1 was confirmed by the successful solution and refinement of the structure. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. Hydrogen atoms bonded to carbon were placed in geometrically idealized positions and included as riding atoms. The water hydrogen atoms were located in difference maps and refined isotropically with all O-H distances restrained to be similar (SHELX SADI instruction, six restraints). The largest residual electron density peak is located 0.92 Å from the uranium atom. Crystallographic data are given in Table 1. Selected bond distances and angles are given in Table 2, and hydrogen bonds are detailed in Table 3.

Ground crystals of 1 were used to collect PXRD patterns using a Rigaku Ultima IV Powder Diffractometer equipped with a high speed DTex detector (Cu Kα radiation λ = 1.5418 Å) over the 2θ range of 5–80°, with a step size of 0.02° and a scan speed of 10°/min. The measured pattern of 1 matches the diffraction pattern generated by CrystalMaker 8.0 using the single-crystal data, and does not reveal any measurable impurities in the sample (Fig. 1).
elements.clean_text:
Powder X-Ray Diffraction

Ground crystals of 1 were used to collect PXRD patterns using a Rigaku Ultima IV Powder Diffractometer equipped with a high speed DTex detector (Cu Kα radiation λ = 1.5418 Å) over the 2θ range of 5-80°, with a step size of 0.02° and a scan speed of 10°/min. The measured pattern of 1 matches the diffraction pattern generated by CrystalMaker 8.0 using the single-crystal data, and does not reveal any measurable impurities in the sample (Fig. 1).

elements.content: Powder X-ray diffraction pattern of 1. The blue pattern is the observed data. The black pattern is the calculated data (Color figure online)
elements.clean_text: Fig. 1Powder X-ray diffraction pattern of 1. The blue pattern is the observed data. The black pattern is the calculated data (Color figure online)

elements.content: Ground crystals of 1 and ground polycrystalline powders of H2PDC and uranyl acetate were used to collect diffuse-reflectance spectra using a Perkin-Elmer Lambda 35 UV–vis scanning spectrometer equipped with an integrating sphere. The raw data were converted from reflection to absorbance by the use of the Kubelka–Munk function.
elements.clean_text:
UV-Vis Spectrometry

Ground crystals of 1 and ground polycrystalline powders of H2PDC and uranyl acetate were used to collect diffuse-reflectance spectra using a Perkin-Elmer Lambda 35 UV-vis scanning spectrometer equipped with an integrating sphere. The raw data were converted from reflection to absorbance by the use of the Kubelka-Munk function.

elements.content: Ground crystals of 1 and ground polycrystalline powders of H2PDC and uranyl acetate were used to collect excitation and emission spectra using a Perkin-Elmer LS 55 Fluorescence Spectrometer. All measurements were collected at room temperature. Emission spectra were collected with excitation at 335 nm and an excitation filter at 390 nm. Excitation spectra were collected with emission at 513 nm.
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescence Measurements

Ground crystals of 1 and ground polycrystalline powders of H2PDC and uranyl acetate were used to collect excitation and emission spectra using a Perkin-Elmer LS 55 Fluorescence Spectrometer. All measurements were collected at room temperature. Emission spectra were collected with excitation at 335 nm and an excitation filter at 390 nm. Excitation spectra were collected with emission at 513 nm.

elements.content: The asymmetric unit consists of one UO22+ group, two sodium atoms, two PDC ligands and two water molecules, as shown in Fig. 2. Each PDC ligand chelates one uranyl cation with both a pyridyl nitrogen and a carboxylate oxygen, and links that uranyl center to a second uranyl center via an oxygen of the second carboxylate group. Thus, the uranyl groups are linked together into chains as shown in Fig. 3. The carboxylate groups are also extensively coordinated to sodium ions, and form clusters with sodium and water via both covalent and hydrogen bonds, as shown in Fig. 4. Overall, a three dimensional network is formed, as shown in Fig. 5.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structural Description of Na2(H2O)2UO2(PDC)2 (1)

The asymmetric unit consists of one UO22+ group, two sodium atoms, two PDC ligands and two water molecules, as shown in Fig. 2. Each PDC ligand chelates one uranyl cation with both a pyridyl nitrogen and a carboxylate oxygen, and links that uranyl center to a second uranyl center via an oxygen of the second carboxylate group. Thus, the uranyl groups are linked together into chains as shown in Fig. 3. The carboxylate groups are also extensively coordinated to sodium ions, and form clusters with sodium and water via both covalent and hydrogen bonds, as shown in Fig. 4. Overall, a three dimensional network is formed, as shown in Fig. 5.

elements.content: A segment of the three dimensional framework of 1. Atoms of the asymmetric unit are shown with black labels, whereas symmetry-equivalent atoms are shown with gray labels. Displacement ellipsoids are drawn at the 60 % probability level

elements.content: Each set of four sodium ions are bridged into clusters by carboxylate and water groups. Two clusters are shown here, and their hydrogen bond linkages along the crystallographic a axis are indicated by the dotted red lines (Color figure online)

elements.content: As can be seen in Figs. 6 and 7, the primary source of the photoluminescent properties of compound 1 is the uranyl cation. A slight blue shift of the luminescence occurs, but overall the typical multi-band signature of U(VI) is in evidence. A lower excitation band near that of the uncoordinated H2PDC molecule is also present near 230 nm in addition to the typical regions of excitation for U(VI). The UV–vis absorbance is very broad, as is typically observed for many U(VI) compounds (Fig. 8) [19, 20].
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescence and UV-Vis Absorbance

As can be seen in Figs. 6 and 7, the primary source of the photoluminescent properties of compound 1 is the uranyl cation. A slight blue shift of the luminescence occurs, but overall the typical multi-band signature of U(VI) is in evidence. A lower excitation band near that of the uncoordinated H2PDC molecule is also present near 230 nm in addition to the typical regions of excitation for U(VI). The UV-vis absorbance is very broad, as is typically observed for many U(VI) compounds (Fig. 8) [19, 20].

elements.content: Emission spectra of H2PDC (blue, top); Na2(H2O)2UO2(PDC)2 (1) (red, middle); UO2(CH3COO)2 (green, bottom). All samples were excited at 335 nm (Color figure online)

elements.content: A new uranium containing framework material was synthesized hydrothermally and characterized via single-crystal diffraction, powder X-ray diffraction, luminescence spectroscopy, and UV–vis spectroscopy.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

A new uranium containing framework material was synthesized hydrothermally and characterized via single-crystal diffraction, powder X-ray diffraction, luminescence spectroscopy, and UV-vis spectroscopy.
